elements.content: The extensive production and large-scale use of perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) have raised their presence in aquatic environments worldwide. Thus, the facile and reliable screening of PFASs in aqueous systems is of great significance. Herein, we designed a novel fluorescent sensor array for the rapid screening and discrimination of multiple PFASs in water. The sensor array comprised three highly stable zirconium porphyrinic luminescent metal–organic frameworks (i.e., PCNs) with different topological structures. The sensing mechanism was based on the static fluorescence quenching of PCNs by PFASs upon their adsorptive interactions. The fluorescence response patterns were characteristic for each PFAS because of their different adsorption affinities toward different PCNs. Through the interpretation of response patterns by statistical methods, the proposed PCN array successfully discriminated six different kinds of PFASs, each PFAS at different concentrations and PFAS mixtures at different molar ratios. The practicability of this array was further verified by effectively discriminating PFASs in two real water samples. Remarkably, the PCN sensors exhibited a very short response time toward PFASs (within 10 s) due to the ordered pore structure allowing fast PFAS diffusion. This study not only provides a facile method for rapid PFAS screening in waters but also broadens the application of luminescent metal–organic frameworks and array techniques in sensing fields.

Introduction

Perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) have been widely used in industrial production and commercial products, such as surfactants, refrigerants, paints, fire-extinguishing foams, and cosmetics, due to their excellent stability, high surface activity, and unique hydrophobic and oleophobic properties. As a result of extensive production and large-scale use, PFASs have been released into the environment in large quantities and have now become global environmental pollutants detected in various environmental medias, wildlife, and humans. PFASs are persistent and bioaccumulative and have potential developmental toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and immunotoxicity. In 2009, perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS), a typical and predominant type of PFASs, and its salts were included in the new list of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in the Stockholm Convention; perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and its related chemicals were then added to the list in 2019. Aquatic environments are an important sink for PFASs because of their low volatility and good water solubility. Therefore, the rapid and reliable screening and detection of PFASs in water are of great significance. Conventional detection methods for PFASs rely heavily on high-performance liquid chromatography or liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. These methods often require complicated sample preparation, expensive instruments, time-consuming operation, and well-trained personnel, which limit their wide application. Thus, it is still in high demand to develop a facile and cost-effective method for PFAS detection.

elements.content: The fluorescence detection method has attracted increasing interest due to its sensitivity, simplicity, and rapidity and has been used in many fields for the detection of target analytes. Recently, several fluorescent sensors have been developed and are being used to detect PFASs, including fluorescent dyes and nanomaterials. However, the reported individual sensors can only detect one given PFAS at a time and were almost impossible to distinguish multiple PFASs due to the similarities in structures and reactivities. Considering the practical needs, it is important to develop a simple and effective fluorescence detection method, which can be used not only for quantitative determination but also for the discrimination of multiple PFASs. The array sensing technique offers the possibility of simultaneous sensing and discrimination of chemicals with similar structural or physical/chemical properties. Depending on the different interactions between sensor elements and analytes, the sensor array produces a unique response pattern for each target analyte. Then, a variety of analytes can be discriminated by the generated cross-response array data with the assistance of statistical analysis tools. So far, the array sensing technique has been applied in the discrimination of phosphates, proteins, thiols, metal ions, and pesticides. Recently, the discrimination of multiple PFASs was successfully achieved by Yin et al. using a fluorescence sensor array based on upconversion nanoparticles, suggesting the great potential of the array technique in PFAS sensing.

elements.content: Luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) are a class of luminescent materials with ultrahigh porosity, specific surface area, as well as structural diversity and tunability. These properties endow LMOF-based sensors with excellent sensitivity, selectivity, and diversity of luminescence properties, which make LMOFs promising for a wide range of applications in the field of fluorescence sensing, such as volatile organic compounds, biomolecules, heavy metals, explosives, and so forth. Very recently, a few LMOF-based sensor arrays have also been explored for the fluorescence discrimination of chemicals, such as anionic sulfonate surfactants and phosphates. Based on this, we envision that LMOFs may effectively perform the role of sensor arrays for PFAS detection and discrimination.

elements.content: Herein, we present a novel fluorescent sensor array, based on three water-stable zirconium porphyrinic LMOFs (PCNs, i.e., PCN-222, PCN-223, and PCN-224), for the screening and discrimination of PFASs in aqueous solutions. The PCNs exhibited stable red fluorescence emission under light excitation at 430 nm. In the presence of PFASs, the emission of PCNs declined because of the static quenching upon their adsorptive interactions with the PFASs (a). Diverse fluorescence quenching response patterns were generated for different PFASs due to their different adsorption affinities toward the three different PCNs (b). Through the interpretation by linear discriminant analysis (LDA) and hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA), the response patterns were successfully used as fingerprints to discriminate and detect six different PFASs in water (c). The feasibility for discriminating PFASs mixed in different proportions was also verified. Finally, we evaluated the potential application of the proposed sensor array for PFAS discrimination in two real water samples. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on the simultaneous screening and discrimination of multiple PFASs using the LMOF sensor array.

The obtained data were processed with LDA and HCA to identify the PFASs. The discrimination ability of the PCN sensor array toward individual PFASs with varying concentrations and different PFAS mixtures as well as its applicability in real water samples were examined in a similar way.

The SEM images (a∼c) show that the three PCNs had different crystal morphologies, which were rod-shaped, shuttle-shaped, and cubic-shaped for PCN-222, PCN-223, and PCN-224, respectively. The observed morphologies of the PCNs are consistent with those reported in earlier studies. d–f displays the XRD patterns of the as-synthesized PCNs, which are in good agreement with their simulated ones. The BET surface area was measured to be 2080, 1827, and 1826 m2/g for PCN-222, PCN-223, and PCN-224, respectively, coinciding with the reported values (e.g., 2223 m2/g for PCN-222, 1809 m2/g for PCN-223, and 1413 m2/g for PCN-224). The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the three PCNs are shown in Figure S1 in Supporting Information. The pore size distributions, as estimated by the DFT simulation (see the inset of Figure S1), suggested that all three PCNs possessed ordered pore structures. The pore sizes were estimated to be 1.2 and 3.2 nm for PCN-222, 1.2 nm for PCN-223, and 1.4 and 2.2 nm for PCN-224, which are consistent with the cage sizes of the crystal structures as well as the literature values for respective PCNs. These results demonstrate the successful synthesis of PCNs. We also investigated the spectroscopic properties of the three PCNs. The UV–vis absorption spectrum of each PCN showed a strong Soret peak around 430 nm and four Q-bands in the range of 500–700 nm (Figure S2), which are the characteristic absorption peaks of the porphyrin linker (i.e., TCPP). The fluorescence excitation–emission matrix (EEM) spectra of all three PCNs exhibited a broad fluorescence area (λex ranging from 350–450 nm and λem ranging from 640–760 nm) with the peak located at around λex of 430 nm and λem of 660 nm (Figure S3a–c). Thus, a wavelength pair of λex 430 nm/λem 660 nm was selected to examine the sensing performance of the PCN sensor array. Figure S3d–f displays the fluorescence emission spectra of the PCN suspensions at λex 430 nm. The three PCNs exhibited different emission spectra due to the difference in ligand-to-metal charge transfer resulting from their distinct zirconium node connectivity (i.e., number of the coordinated linker). Within the environmentally relevant pH range (i.e., pH 5.0–8.0), the fluorescence emission intensities of the PCNs were stable. We then monitored the fluorescence intensity of PCNs at λex 430 nm/λem 660 nm as a function of the irradiation time. The fluctuation of the fluorescence intensity was less than 5% within the examined 60 min of irradiation (Figure S3g–i), suggesting good water and fluorescence stabilities of PCNs.

elements.content: After the successful synthesis of PCNs, we examined the fluorescence responses of the PCNs toward PFASs. As shown in a–c, the fluorescence emission of all three PCNs can be quenched by PFASs, and the quenching efficiencies increased with increasing PFAS concentrations (d and S4a,b). Thus, the PCNs can be applied to the fluorescence screening of PFASs. It is noteworthy that the fluorescence quenching of PCNs by PFASs reached the equilibrium almost instantaneously (within the initial 10 s, e and S4c,d), owing to the ordered pore structure and large surface area of PCNs that facilitated PFAS diffusion. The fast response and good fluorescence stability benefit the sensing of PFASs in aqueous environments. Moreover, we found that different PCN sensors exhibited different fluorescence quenching responses upon exposure to PFASs. For example, the fluorescence of PCN-223 (10 μg/mL) was quenched by approximately 75% in the presence of 2 μg/mL PFDA but only by 30% by PFOA at the same concentration; the quenching percentage was about 50 and 40% for 10 μg/mL PCN-222 and PCN-224 by 2 μg/mL PFOA, respectively (). The difference in the fluorescence response of the three different PCNs mainly resulted from their diverse adsorption affinities toward different PFASs (see more discussion below). These results suggest the discrimination potential of the PCN array toward PFASs.

elements.content: The discrimination ability of the PCN array against individual PFASs with varying concentrations was examined to verify their quantification function. We take the quantification of PFOA as an example. The heat map visually reflected the different fluorescence responses of the sensors to PFOA with different concentrations (a). In the LDA pattern (b), different concentrations of PFOA (ranging from 0.1 to 10 μg/mL) were distinguished clearly without overlap, confirming the concentration discrimination ability of the PCN array. Notably, factor 1 in the plot exceeded 95%. Thus, factor 1 can be utilized alone for the quantitative discrimination of PFOA. The value of factor 1 increased with increasing the PFOA concentration and exhibited a good linear relationship in the concentration range of 0.1–2 μg/mL (R 2 = 0.98, c). elements.content: The emission quenching of a fluorescent sensor can be generally attributed to static quenching, dynamic quenching, and/or the inner filter effect. Because there is no spectrum overlap between the PFAS UV–vis absorbance and PCN fluorescence emission (a), the inner filter effect cannot occur in the PCN/PFAS systems. We speculated that the fluorescence quenching response of the PCNs to PFASs was due to the static quenching upon their adsorptive interactions. To explore the mechanism, we characterized the PCNs before and after the addition of PFASs. As shown in b and S9, the UV–vis absorption intensity of the PCNs declined gradually with the addition of all tested PFASs, indicating the formation of ground-state PCN–PFAS complexes upon the adsorption process. Moreover, the fluorescence decay curves of the PCNs in the absence or presence of PFASs almost overlapped (c and S10), and the measured fluorescence lifetimes were essentially constant (see Table S3). These observations confirmed that the quenching was mainly caused by the static quenching originating from the formation of PCN–PFAS complexes rather than by dynamic collision. The quenching constant (k q) can also be regarded as a reference to infer the quenching mechanism. The k q values determined from the Stern–Volmer equation were in the range of 0.38–4.36 × 1014 M–1 S–1 for PCNs by the six PFASs (see details in Figure S11), much larger than the limiting diffusion rate constant (2.0 × 1010 M–1 S–1 ), which are also consistent with the static quenching mechanism.

elements.content: The adsorption of the PFASs on PCNs was confirmed by the results of batch adsorption experiments. At an initial concentration of 2 μg/mL, approximately 8–17% of PFHxA, 14–25% of PFHpA, 28–40% of PFOA, 50–75% of PFNA, 80–95% of PFDA, and 65–95% of PFOS were adsorbed by the three PCNs (10 μg/mL) (d). elements.content: Considering the molecular structure of PFASs, their adsorption on the PCNs were expected to be mainly driven by hydrophobic interactions with the PCN pore surface and coordination with the zirconium clusters. The three PCNs are different in zirconium node connectivity, pore size, and surface area. Meanwhile, the tested PFASs have various perfluoroalkyl chain lengths and/or functional groups (i.e., carboxylic acid and sulfonic acid groups, see chemical structures in Table S1). Thus, different PCNs are expected to exhibit different adsorption affinities to different PFASs, leading to different fluorescence quenching responses. In line with this, under the same tested adsorption conditions (2 μg/mL of PFASs and 10 μg/mL PCNs), the adsorption ratio of each PFAS was different on the three PCNs (d). For all three PCNs, the adsorption ratio increased with the increase of the perfluoroalkyl chain length of PFASs with the only exception of PFOS. The hydrophobicity of the PFASs increases with their perfluoroalkyl chain length, as reflected by the n-octanol–water partition coefficient (K OW, Table S1). Thus, this result suggested the key role of hydrophobic interactions in PFAS adsorption to the PCNs. Despite the same or even shorter perfluoroalkyl chain length, PFOS had higher adsorption than PFOA and PFNA, indicative of the role of functional groups on PFAS adsorption. This is in agreement with the observations in previous works. Notably, the order of the adsorption ratios of the six PFASs on each PCN roughly coincided with the order of their fluorescence quenching efficiency, further confirming that the quenching of PCNs by PFASs was caused by static quenching upon adsorption.

The PCNs were prepared by the solvothermal method according to the literature with slight modifications. For the preparation of PCN-222, 75 mg of ZrCl4, 50 mg of TCPP, and 2.7 g of benzoic acid were dissolved in 8 mL of DEF by sonication for 30 min. The mixture was then loaded in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid sample was collected by centrifugation and was washed using DMF and acetone, followed by drying at 80 °C under vacuum for 12 h. To remove the unreacted ligands, metal salts, and/or the trapped benzoic acid, the abovementioned resulted materials were further treated by immersion in DMF/HCl (8 mol/L HCl in 40 mL DMF) solution at 120 °C for 12 h. Then, the materials were washed with DMF and acetone, followed by immersion in acetone for 24 h to exchange the nonvolatile DMF. After drying under vacuum for 6 h, the obtained materials were collected as PCN-222.

To prepare PCN-223, 21 mg of ZrCl4 and 30 mg of TCPP were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF by sonication for 10 min. Then, 6 mL of propionic acid was added to the mixture, which was further sonicated. The mixture was then loaded in a Teflon-lined high pressure autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 16 h. As for the preparation of PCN-224, 60 mg of ZrOCl2·8H2O and 32 mg of TCPP were dissolved in 8 mL of DMF, followed by the addition of formic acid (1380 μL) and 3,3-dimethylbutanoic acid (1620 μL). After sonication for 10 min, the mixture was heated in a high-pressure autoclave at 120 °C for 12 h. The following washing and purification steps of PCN-223 and PCN-224 were the same as those of PCN-222.

In this study, three PCNs with different topological structures were selected to construct the sensor array for PFAS discrimination, including 8-connected PCN-222 with csq topology, 12-connected PCN-223 with shp topology, and 6-connected PCN-224 with she topology. The SEM images (a∼c) show that the three PCNs had different crystal morphologies, which were rod-shaped, shuttle-shaped, and cubic-shaped for PCN-222, PCN-223, and PCN-224, respectively. The observed morphologies of the PCNs are consistent with those reported in earlier studies. d–f displays the XRD patterns of the as-synthesized PCNs, which are in good agreement with their simulated ones. The BET surface area was measured to be 2080, 1827, and 1826 m2/g for PCN-222, PCN-223, and PCN-224, respectively, coinciding with the reported values (e.g., 2223 m2/g for PCN-222, 1809 m2/g for PCN-223, and 1413 m2/g for PCN-224). The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the three PCNs are shown in Figure S1 in Supporting Information. The pore size distributions, as estimated by the DFT simulation (see the inset of Figure S1), suggested that all three PCNs possessed ordered pore structures. The pore sizes were estimated to be 1.2 and 3.2 nm for PCN-222, 1.2 nm for PCN-223, and 1.4 and 2.2 nm for PCN-224, which are consistent with the cage sizes of the crystal structures as well as the literature values for respective PCNs. These results demonstrate the successful synthesis of PCNs. We also investigated the spectroscopic properties of the three PCNs. The UV–vis absorption spectrum of each PCN showed a strong Soret peak around 430 nm and four Q-bands in the range of 500–700 nm (Figure S2), which are the characteristic absorption peaks of the porphyrin linker (i.e., TCPP). The fluorescence excitation–emission matrix (EEM) spectra of all three PCNs exhibited a broad fluorescence area (λex ranging from 350–450 nm and λem ranging from 640–760 nm) with the peak located at around λex of 430 nm and λem of 660 nm (Figure S3a–c). Thus, a wavelength pair of λex 430 nm/λem 660 nm was selected to examine the sensing performance of the PCN sensor array. Figure S3d–f displays the fluorescence emission spectra of the PCN suspensions at λex 430 nm. The three PCNs exhibited different emission spectra due to the difference in ligand-to-metal charge transfer resulting from their distinct zirconium node connectivity (i.e., number of the coordinated linker). Within the environmentally relevant pH range (i.e., pH 5.0–8.0), the fluorescence emission intensities of the PCNs were stable. We then monitored the fluorescence intensity of PCNs at λex 430 nm/λem 660 nm as a function of the irradiation time. The fluctuation of the fluorescence intensity was less than 5% within the examined 60 min of irradiation (Figure S3g–i), suggesting good water and fluorescence stabilities of PCNs.

The discrimination ability of the PCN array against individual PFASs with varying concentrations was examined to verify their quantification function. We take the quantification of PFOA as an example. The heat map visually reflected the different fluorescence responses of the sensors to PFOA with different concentrations (a). In the LDA pattern (b), different concentrations of PFOA (ranging from 0.1 to 10 μg/mL) were distinguished clearly without overlap, confirming the concentration discrimination ability of the PCN array. Notably, factor 1 in the plot exceeded 95%. Thus, factor 1 can be utilized alone for the quantitative discrimination of PFOA. The value of factor 1 increased with increasing the PFOA concentration and exhibited a good linear relationship in the concentration range of 0.1–2 μg/mL (R 2 = 0.98, c). Similar good linear relationships (R 2 > 0.98) were also found for other tested PFASs except for PFHxA that had the lowest quenching efficiency (Figure S7). The linear ranges were 0.1–2 μg/mL for PFHpA and PFNA and 0.1–1 μg/mL for PFDA and PFOS. The good linear correlation between factor 1 and PFAS concentration indicated that quantitative analysis of an individual PFAS can be realized by the PCN sensor array. On the basis of the abovementioned linear correlations, limits of detection (LOD) of the proposed array for PFASs were subsequently determined using the IUPAC criteria (3σ/slope, where σ is the standard deviation of the factor 1 value without the presence of PFASs). The LOD was approximately 10–8 mol/L (0.044, 0.046, 0.047, 0.045, and 0.036 μg/mL for PFHpA, PFOA, PFNA, PFDA, and PFOS, respectively), comparable to that obtained by previously reported fluorescent sensors (e.g., 10–11–10–5 mol/L, Table S2).

Sensing Mechanism of the PCN Array

The emission quenching of a fluorescent sensor can be generally attributed to static quenching, dynamic quenching, and/or the inner filter effect. Because there is no spectrum overlap between the PFAS UV–vis absorbance and PCN fluorescence emission (a), the inner filter effect cannot occur in the PCN/PFAS systems. We speculated that the fluorescence quenching response of the PCNs to PFASs was due to the static quenching upon their adsorptive interactions. To explore the mechanism, we characterized the PCNs before and after the addition of PFASs. As shown in b and S9, the UV–vis absorption intensity of the PCNs declined gradually with the addition of all tested PFASs, indicating the formation of ground-state PCN–PFAS complexes upon the adsorption process. Moreover, the fluorescence decay curves of the PCNs in the absence or presence of PFASs almost overlapped (c and S10), and the measured fluorescence lifetimes were essentially constant (see Table S3). These observations confirmed that the quenching was mainly caused by the static quenching originating from the formation of PCN–PFAS complexes rather than by dynamic collision. The quenching constant (k q) can also be regarded as a reference to infer the quenching mechanism. The k q values determined from the Stern–Volmer equation were in the range of 0.38–4.36 × 1014 M–1 S–1 for PCNs by the six PFASs (see details in Figure S11), much larger than the limiting diffusion rate constant (2.0 × 1010 M–1 S–1 ), which are also consistent with the static quenching mechanism.

The adsorption of the PFASs on PCNs was confirmed by the results of batch adsorption experiments. At an initial concentration of 2 μg/mL, approximately 8–17% of PFHxA, 14–25% of PFHpA, 28–40% of PFOA, 50–75% of PFNA, 80–95% of PFDA, and 65–95% of PFOS were adsorbed by the three PCNs (10 μg/mL) (d). We further characterized the PCNs after PFAS adsorption. e and S12 show the EDS mappings of PCNs after adsorption of PFOA. The F element was uniformly distributed on the crystals of PCNs, consistent with their adsorption toward PFOA. The EDS mapping result also revealed the structure integrity of PCNs after adsorption, in line with their good water stability. FTIR spectroscopy analysis provided consistent results. After adsorption, the FTIR spectra of PCNs exhibited no significant change in shape and position of the absorption bands except for the appearance of a new band characteristic of PFOA molecules (the C–F stretching vibration band at around 1240 cm–1, Figure S13).
